subject: Logging not using oslo.i18n guidelines (scheduler)
commit_message:
Logging not using oslo.i18n guidelines (scheduler)

Multi-patch set for easier chunks. This one addresses
the scheduler cinder directory.

There have been quite a few instances found where the
i18n guidelines are not being followed. I believe this
has helped lead to some of the confusion around how to
correctly do this. Other developers see this code and
assume it is an example of the correct usage.

This patch attempts to clean up most of those violations
in the existing codebase to hopefully help avoid some of
that confusion in reviews.

Some issues address:
* Correct log translation markers for different log levels
* Passing format values as arguments to call, not preformatting
* Not forcing translation via six.text_type and others

Guidelines can be found here:
http://docs.openstack.org/developer/oslo.i18n/guidelines.html

Hacking checks will not be able to identify all violations of
the guidelines, but it could be useful for catching obvious
one such as LOG.info("No markers!").

subject: Bulk upload: treat user xattrs as object metadata
commit_message:
Bulk upload: treat user xattrs as object metadata

Currently, if you PUT a single object, then you can also associate
metadata with it by putting it in the request headers, prefixed with
"X-Object-Meta". However, if you're bulk-uploading objects, then you
have no way to assign any metadata.

The tar file format* allows for arbitrary UTF-8 key/value pairs to be
associated with each file in an archive (as well as with the archive
itself, but we don't care about that here). If a file has extended
attributes, then tar will store those as key/value pairs.

This commit makes bulk upload read those extended attributes, if
present, and convert those to Swift object metadata. Attributes
starting with "user.meta" are converted to object metadata, and
"user.mime_type"** is converted to Content-Type.

For example, if you have a file "setup.py":

    $ setfattr -n user.mime_type -v "application/python-setup" setup.py
    $ setfattr -n user.meta.lunch -v "burger and fries" setup.py
    $ setfattr -n user.meta.dinner -v "baked ziti" setup.py
    $ setfattr -n user.stuff -v "whee" setup.py

This will get translated to headers:

    Content-Type: application/python-setup
    X-Object-Meta-Lunch: burger and fries
    X-Object-Meta-Dinner: baked ziti

Swift will handle xattrs stored by both GNU and BSD tar***. Only
xattrs user.mime_type and user.meta.* are processed; others are
ignored.

This brings bulk upload much closer to feature-parity with non-bulk upload.

* The POSIX 1003.1-2001 (pax) format, at least. There are a few
  different, mutually-incompatible tar formats out there, because of
  course there are. This is the default format on GNU tar 1.27.1 or
  later.

** http://standards.freedesktop.org/shared-mime-info-spec/latest/ar01s02.html#idm140622087713936

*** Even with pax-format tarballs, different encoders store xattrs
    slightly differently; for example, GNU tar stores the xattr
    "user.rubberducky" as pax header "SCHILY.xattr.user.rubberducky",
    while BSD tar (which uses libarchive) stores it as
    "LIBARCHIVE.xattr.user.rubberducky". One might wonder if this is
    some programmer's attempt at job security.

Change-Id: I5e3ce87d31054f5239e86d47c45adbde2bb93640

subject: Fixed YAQL tag leakage to YAML loader
commit_message:
Fixed YAQL tag leakage to YAML loader

Implicit yaml tag resolver being registered for YaqlYamlLoader (which is
user to load MuranoPL classes as YAML documents with embedded YAQL
statements) was being registered in the default YAML Dumper which is
used for any YAML serialization.

This was leading to inability to load more then one HOT-based package
per API service lifetime: the first package which was uploaded was
causing the leakage of YAQL statements into the global tag resolver.
This global resolver was used for all subsequent load attempts, so plain
yaml documents with Heat templates were attempted to be loaded as
MuranoPL classes.

This patch fixes this behavior by registering the implicit resolver
without helper method (which actually registers the resolvers at default
Dumper).

Notify a consumer that all dependenices injected

In the current DI implementation a provider is registered when it is
constructed, without providing any prior information. Technically we
can't guarantee that a dependency will be injected before a consumer
object construction, because the provider object could be instantiated
later on. Moreover this problem is not applicable just to __init__
method, the consumer object is inconsistent state for some time and any
methods which rely on injected attribute will fail during this period.

This fix adds a callback method _dependencies_injected which a consumer
may implement. This method will be invoked when all required
dependencies has been injected.

Change-Id: I7e04f04dadd99da73eca5a446b4958b0f0d0feb9
Closes-Bug: #1180136

subject: Fixed container user create issue
commit_message:
Fixed container user create issue

This patch resolves an issue where the LXC container create user
password is being hard coded due to how the default LXC container
template is being used. The template allows for a container to be
created without specifying a password at create time however when
doing this the default LXC template will create a user and a
password based on the linux distribution's name. This means that
all users of a "ubuntu" template will have a "ubuntu" user which
will have a "ubuntu" password. While the container user must exist
the password does not need to be known to the end user/deployer
because there are other means to gain access to a container from
within the host. So to correct this issue for all deployers as
well as all future deployments this patch ensures that the container
user is created with a random password and provides for an additional
tag to allow the deployer to regenerate the password at will.

subject: Generate stack events for stack state transitions
commit_message:
Generate stack events for stack state transitions

Currently, the event-list output is very resource-centric, despite
being scoped to the stack from an API path perspective.

This, combined with the fact that the stack updated_at timestamp
is only updated after a succesful update (ref bug #1193269) makes
it impossible to derive the time when an update started via any API.

This is a problem when trying to use the new hook/breakpoint API,
because it's necessary to poll for all events since the most recent
update started, disregarding any stale hook events from previous
updates (which may have failed or timed out without the hooks getting
cleared).

To work around this, add an event for each stack state transition,
such that you can detect the transition to UPDATE_IN_PROGRESS,
then use that event as a marker to get post-update-started events.

Without this (or some other way to determine when the stack update
started), the hooks pre-update functionality landed for kilo is
not really usable (particularly mechanically via scripts).

subject: Fixed container user create issue
commit_message:
Fixed container user create issue

This patch resolves an issue where the LXC container create user
password is being hard coded due to how the default LXC container
template is being used. The template allows for a container to be
created without specifying a password at create time however when
doing this the default LXC template will create a user and a
password based on the linux distribution's name. This means that
all users of a "ubuntu" template will have a "ubuntu" user which
will have a "ubuntu" password. While the container user must exist
the password does not need to be known to the end user/deployer
because there are other means to gain access to a container from
within the host. So to correct this issue for all deployers as
well as all future deployments this patch ensures that the container
user is created with a random password and provides for an additional
tag to allow the deployer to regenerate the password at will.

subject: New API allow clients to execute a pipeline of commands
commit_message:
New API allow clients to execute a pipeline of commands

Currently, several clients of execute() who wish to execute a pipeline
of commands need to do this using a literal string and specifying
"shell=True" in the invocation of subprocess.Popen(). This change
allows users to construct a pipeline of commands, potentially
including sudo, and execute that entire pipeline without requiring
shell=True.

The new API execute_pipeline() takes a subset of the parameters that
execute() accepts and constructs and executes the pipeline, returning
the stdout, stderr and returncode. Similar to execute() this API will
log some information after sanitizing through strutils.mask_password()
and will return stdout and stderr that have been similarly
sanitized.

Also, similar to execute() this API computes total time and logs it in
the same way that execute() does.

I have also reviewed the package 'sarge' and a very quick assessment
indicates that it isn't as fast as the present implementation and in
the short term, I think an implementation similar to execute() would
be preferable. I'll look to wrap sarge and potentially reimplement
processutils based on it independently.

Test cases have been proposed as well.

subject: Add heartbeat support to kombu
commit_message:
Add heartbeat support to kombu

This change adds heartbeat support for kombu by passing in heartbeat parameter
of default value 60 second and adding a thread(eventlet) that spawns after heartbeat/2
seconds to check for the connection.

This is a critical bug fix for cases where network connections are not reliable.
One of my test scenario had a NAT between nova-compute and the nova-conductor/nova-scheduler.
NAT devices are known to drop idle connections without telling corresponding parties of
the state of the connection. This behavior caused interesting 'hung' operation on nova side.

Here are the details:
Setup:

Nova-Conduct/Scheduler are running on a machine 'P' along with Broker
Nova-compute C is running on a virtual machine local at my workplace behind a NAT.
Both P, C are using Kombu 3.0.16 (https://pypi.python.org/pypi/kombu)

P creates a 'topic' exchange and create a Queue (nova_compute_<id>) which needs acknowledgements.
C waits for the message upon arrival sends an ack back to B.

Scenarios:

Positive:
P and C are connected to B, P publishes messages, C receives it and everything works fine.

Negative:
While C is connected to B,

step-1) I disconnect the 'virtual network' which disconnects the virtual machine C is running on.
So effectively C is not reachable anymore. (This should be similar to unplugging network cable to a machine)

At this point of time, I observed the following on broker machine:

rabbitmqctl list_connections name state timeout : it shows the connection between the B and C as running, timeout value=0
rabbitmqctl list_queues name messages_ready messages_unacknowledged: shows name and both ready and unacked messages =0

step-2) I then publish a message from P on the Q.

Now

rabbitmqctl list_connections name state timeout : it shows the connection between the B and C as running, timeout value=0
rabbitmqctl list_queues name messages_ready messages_unacknowledged: shows name and both ready =0 and unacked messages =1

step-3) I then publish another message from P on the Q.

Now

rabbitmqctl list_connections name state timeout : it shows the connection between the B and C as running, timeout value=0
rabbitmqctl list_queues name messages_ready messages_unacknowledged: shows name and both ready =0 and unacked messages =2

step-4) I plug 'connect' the network for C again but I never see the messages on the C they remain in the unacked state > 8 hrs (I didn't check after that).

Solution:
After the fix, the timeout value in Step-1,2,3 = 60 and step-4 succeeds and the messages are delivered.

Some references:

http://kombu.readthedocs.org/en/latest/reference/kombu.connection.html
https://www.rabbitmq.com/amqp-0-9-1-reference.html
https://github.com/celery/py-amqp/

subject: Implement message flow control using link credit
commit_message:
Implement message flow control using link credit

This change implements a scheme for managing link credit for consumer
links.  There are two different link use cases in this driver, each
of which employs its own credit management scheme:

The per-connection RPC reply link: the RPC sender is rate limited
given the synchronous nature of the RPC implementation.  Also, we need
to avoid having a 'slow' RPC client block an RPC server. Therefore the
shared RPC reply link does not backpressure senders.  It maintains a
credit level in the range of [$reply_credit/2 ... $reply_credit].

The per-target RPC server links: the RPC servers need to be able to
backpressure the broker should the server's backlog of incoming RPC
request messages becomes 'excessive'.  This is done by implementing a
high/low watermark on the queue of incoming RPC request messages.
When the number of queued RPC request messages becomes greater than
$listener_max_backlog, the driver will stop granting credit on all
receive links associated with the RPC server's subscription to its
target.  When the number of queued RPC requests drops to less than
$listener_low_backlog, credit will resume being granted to the receive
links.  The scheme for maintaining credit on the topic's receive links
(when not blocking) is similar to the method used for the
per-connection RPC reply link: the credit level on all links is
maintained in the range [$subscription_credit/2
... $subscription_credit].

Change-Id: If2a00139123d069d6968d6451d974d8aa183dcc4
Closes-Bug: #1367911

Removing a hash from a line in a config file without also removing

subject: Prevent a UnicodeDecodeError in the s3token middleware
commit_message:
Prevent a UnicodeDecodeError in the s3token middleware

Mixing "str" and "unicode" can lead to a UnicodeDecodeError. We encode unicode
values before using them with text strings.

The bug occurs if the URL contains a non-ASCII character in the tenant id:
"hého" in "/v1/AUTH_cfa/c/hého" ("/v1/AUTH_cfa/c/h\xc3\xa9ho" in UTF-8) for
example.

The bug occurs on Python 2 in s3_token.py because the tenant id is retrieved
from identity_info['access']['token']['tenant'] and identity_info comes from
resp.json().

The problem is that in Python, the JSON decoder always create Unicode strings.
Example in Python 2:

>>> json.loads('{"key": "value"}') {u'key': u'value'}

There is no issue in Python 3, since all text strings are Unicode.

subject: Type conflict in trusted_filter.py using attestation_port default value
commit_message:
Type conflict in trusted_filter.py using attestation_port default value

When trusted filter (nova/nova/scheduler/filters/trusted_filter.py)
in nova scheduler is running with default value of attestation_port:

default='8443'

method _do_request() in AttestationService class has this line:

action_url = "https://%s:%d%s/%s" % (self.host,
self.port, self.api_url, action_url)

It is easy to see that default type of attestation_port is string.
But in action_url self.port is required as integer (%d).
It leads to conflict.

This change provides more tests than is required only to cover this bug
fix. This cases are testing AttestationService _do_request() method
using different status_codes and different texts returned by mocked
request method.
